title: Dreyfus dines with preferred successor
text:
Well, what a confounding sight at Parliament House during Tuesday’s session: right before the House convened for Question Time, there was Labor MP Mark Dreyfus in the Members' Dining Room, alone and deep in conversation with Labor’s unsuccessful Higgins candidate (and fellow barrister) Fiona McLeod.

What put one silk in Canberra during a sitting week is obvious; what took the other there remains nebulous.

The shadow attorney-general, of course, would like to see McLeod succeed him in the safer ALP seat of Isaacs – and like him, she doesn’t live there. But only last week he ardently denied our report that he’s preparing to resign and cause a by-election next year, with the Andrews government preparing to appoint him to the Victorian Court of Appeal.

We’ll see about that. A multitude of spots on the bench will become available for a Justice Dreyfus before the next state election in 2022 – including if the next High Court justice is drawn from the Garden State’s bench.

High Court vacancies are customarily filled by jurists from the same state and Justice Geoffrey Nettle, a Victorian, reaches mandatory retirement age in December next year.
description: Mark Dreyfus lunched in Canberra on Tuesday with his preferred successor, even though he's not leaving.
